title: Loving new mana items?
body:
I know there are a lot of complaints about the new items, and in some cases, those complaints make a lot of sense.

But can we talk about the elegant solution to the {{item:3165}} problem for a sec? This item is basically the only option for most mage mids to rush right now, and the reason is incredibly simple; it gives them everything. Mana, mana regen, damage, and CDR. It's over half of the offensive stats that mages want.

So Riot, being pretty smart with design, goes "you know what? That actually doesn't break the game too badly, so we're just gonna make a bunch of items with Damage, CDR, and Mana and see what happens. You can't have your mana regen anymore, that's nuts, but we'll just give you insanely large mana pools to compensate you for that, no worries."

That's really nice. I'm not sure why mage mains aren't rejoicing and openly weeping on the Boards now; we're *finally* seeing some parity in offensive items between Mages and ADCS. Not complete parity, and I'm okay with that, but at least some decent options for CDR and mana, and a bunch of pretty cool situational items.

Am I the only one that thinks that is the right direction to go? This is an awesome solution to a pervasive problem.

replies.body: obviously the new ap items should have been 200 ap, 600 health, 400 mana 50 armor, 50 magic resist, 25% movespeed, 45% max health burn over 2 seconds, and a passive that heals you for 250% of your ap if you fall below 30% health for 2800 gold. And even then it's still not as good as the adc god tier items, so better buff mages as well

That item doesn't even have Grievous Wounds. Morello's had it, so if the new item doesn't have it, it's garbage.

It's like you don't even play mages, you have literally no idea what you're talking about. How are they supposed to deal with Mundo if they don't have Grievous Wounds? You're probably Meddler in disguise, trying to peddle your terrible balance ideas to the plebs who don't know any better.

What's wrong with reducing the AP a little? I don't see any obvious problems with that. Morellonomicon had 100AP and everyone was fine with it as a rush item.

Edit: jk, they did reduce it 20, I see what you mean. I think rabadon's will be more necessary now if you want a high AP build. But that *does* reduce some of the burst in the game that people are complaining about, does it not?

Except the most complained about burst is a shiv crit from the ADC, too much of it on tanks, duskblade's.. And Zoe. But Zoe will burst anyway even with 20 less AP on her first  item.  They are removing burst from one of the only 2 classes intended to have it.

I like the direction Riot is going with the changes, I'm just a little put off by how much CDR has been added, in addition to all the CDR that already exists in the game (and will still be there after these changes go through).

Like, as an AP enchanter support, my usual build includes {{item:3098}} {{item:3504}} {{item:3107}}, which is already 30% CDR, and then I'd be inclined to buy Twin Shadows (+10% more CDR?), and then either {{item:3285}} or {{item:3003}} would give another 10% CDR plus a bonus 10% CDR on top of that? I mean, I guess I could go {{item:3089}} instead, but the extra mana on {{item:3003}} or {{item:3285}} is highly appealing, especially if I'm gonna have all this extra CDR to permaspam my spells. 

But still. I feel like all this CDR will just make people rage at the "broken" enchanter supports even more ({{champion:37}} {{champion:16}} {{champion:40}} ) when they inevitably build these items and can spam their heals and shields. And I'd really rather not have my supports nerfed to the ground AGAIN because itemization is the problem.

The CDR cap is a useful tool to prevent overstacking of some mechanics, though. 

If you're going {{item:3098}} , {{item:3504}} , {{item:3107}} , it might legit be OP for you to stack a lot of mana (and those passives) on top of that. I dunno.

But yeah, if you want AP, you can go Rabadon's, and if you really want to stack mage items, you can forgo ardent and redemption. *Or*, you can take transcendence and still stack CDR and get both.

That's the point, though. You have options with all of those; the one you want might not be optimal, but it might end up fitting your playstyle and being plenty strong. In an ideal world, that's how that *should* work, right? So they're taking steps in that direction, and I love that.

Good analysis though. I will worry with you a bit about enchanter supports. I think it'll be mitigated by the wider availability of GW for two of those, but Janna is one to keep an eye on. I honestly think she's enough of a balance nightmare to warrant a gameplay update, even without these changes. But I doubt many people share that opinion.
You mean, it was, before they made a rune that not only give you 10% CDR but also give you free AP when you get more CDR than the cap.

The more I think about these changes, the more I feel like they're going to be a disaster that will take months to patch into place. Sure, there's many good things I see coming, and I *like* that, but dangers also loom on the horizon. Liandries is a meme that will be easily fixed√, what I'm *concerned* about is Seraphs.

Seraphs is the new Morellos, and replaces it as the "cookie cutter first item". Offers 89√ AP + 20% CDR on buy, and trades the grievous passive for the ability to immensely scale later on (+50~ AP and a shield), as well as significantly higher mana pools. Basically trades 18 AP + 100 gp for 400 Mana + 20% CDR, which is a significant buff over it's current iteration, ignoring the better buildpath.

Now, this is a problem because we have an entire class of champions (Mana Guzzlers), who are balanced around Seraphs being incredibly hard to get rolling. It's a direct buff to the champions that build it currently (Cassopeia, Ryze), as well as those who really ***really*** want it, but couldn't afford the early game power hit (Hi, Kassadin√√).

Also, it kind of invalidates Ludens as the "Poke Mana Item", it scales fast enough that the window where Ludens is better is incredibly short√√√, and generally poke champions want "assloads of mana" way more than "a dinky on-hit proc" (25% mana refunds *alone* is huge).

Overall, I feel like Riot's got a big beast to wrangle in terms of making Seraphs not have a hardcore power dip in the early game, but also not suffocate out the other options. I trust them to eventually get this right, but I *do* expect some turbulence.

√Already addressed on PBE, apparently.
√√89 AP based on 650 Mana from item, 650 Mana from champ, = 1300, which is 39 AP from the passive.
√√√Though the PBE buff to Ludens helps to alleviate this, it doesn't solve the root issue that *seraphs is a better poke item*.

I think you bring up a good point with seraph's, but it will still take time to amp up. The luden's proc is probably worth the 9 AP, and they actually raised it to 90AP today. 

Nonetheless, I think this is the best critique of the items that I've read. You're right that the balancing act between Luden's and Seraphs may prove to be difficult, and that'll be something to watch. 

Personally, I don't think the intended use of Luden's *is* to be a poke item, though it has certainly ended up that way. If this pushes it to a more burst-oriented role, then that's maybe a good thing?

Thanks. I like the changes they're making on the PBE so far,  and can't find anything to disagree with.

My primary issue is that Seraphs starts out on par with the other items at 0 stacks. Slightly weaker, but has lots more mana. The issue is that it *then* scales super hard and gets a defensive shield. Said scaling might need to get ramped back, maybe something like lower the AP gained from Mana from 3% to 2.5%?

Ludens, at least it's previous iterations, was intended to be an item for poke mages. Also, the AP Itemization post directly references Ludens as the *poke* choice. Whatever else, the **intended** use is as a poke item.

>Lost Chapter upgrades into three 20% CDR, Mana, AP items; Hextech GLP (catch), Ludens (poke) and Archangel's Staff (scaling).

Shifting Ludens to a burst role *might* be a good thing, but when I think "AP item that offers CDR, Mana, and up-front burst damage", the words on my tongue are "Lich Bane".   These two items, while having their minor differences, will step on each others toes a *lot*.

Yeah, you're selling me on that, I think. I like the scaling on it in theory; if it playtests that Luden's just has a lot more poke damage and still adequate mana, it might be a good enough separation, but I think it's a good cause for concern. That's what I'll be watching going forward.

As for the AP items that haven't been touched here, it does say a lot about how they view the class. I would have loved an update to RoA; if Archangels is supposed to be the scaling item, where does that leave RoA? The *other* scaling item? I dunno, I would have liked to see more things touched outside of just these items.

I don't. They nerfed the AP out again, added mana and even more CDR on the CDR overload that we already have, and didn't even give us any good defensive options either, besides health. No armor or MR.

This is another weak attempt at trying to fix AP, and really makes me think they don't know what the hell they are doing.

Not tanky, just let them be able to survive without being deleted after you press Zhonya's. Hourglass has already been nerfed to crap, Veil is situational and not that good of a buy. Those are only two options for AP while AD has

You can compare to AD items all day long, but you're not making a logical connection about why mages need access to similar powers. Do you think every item should have adaptive damage? What's your end goal here, and why do want that?

Mages don't have escapes, they don't have mobility. Yes they have CC but are also gated by cooldowns and mana. They need more options to survive and the ones we have don't cut it with all the damage across the board right now.

I want a better armor/AP item, and another unique MR item as well that mages have the options to choose from instead of just the one hourglass or veil.
So without armor, mr or HP how then would you increase survivability?
Those are the main defensive options there. Without, then you have to rely on heals and shields, playing safe and using CC.

They don't need more survival options, though... They would have to give up so much damage for that that it wouldn't be worth it.

If Riot gave more armor and MR items, they would just be a trap. Just like BC, Maw, etc. are for ADCs. I'm not seeing a universe in which that's a good idea.

Win rates *do* matter. Everyone lost a lot in preseason, and everyone gained a lot. Including mages.

I think it's because for so long there has been really only 1 metric for measuring how much damage an AP champion can deal: "does my Ability power = lots?".

These items sacrifice some of that AP for unique effects, something that AP champions aren't really used to, especially after DFG removal.

I do have some concern over the AP numbers though, in that it may increase reliance on DCap, which even with the +5% buff, still sucks to build (i.e the actual building part), but even then, Meddler said it's something they may change if they deem it necessary.

There's some of that sense I've been looking for!

I also think that mage players forget that CDR = damage. More spells = more damage, so several of these items have significant buffs just because of that. I mean, I think the GLP and Archangels look *much* better now, but we'll see how it is in practice, I guess.

DCap is the biggest concern. I really do hope they look at the build path for it, because that could be a great help in late game builds.
I think it's the right decision, but why's there 500 mana on one item when you can have like 250 or 300 on multiple items that would be in core builds.
